subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] A couple of questions
msgSnippet: ... When I see a 32 written, I think Ah! , not a . (Which doesn t make it wrong, but just tells you my own preference.) Read s manual, page 16, shows a/an
messageBody:
Delrayva wrote:

> 1. How do I write the word "a," as in "a car," "a birthday," etc.?� I
> usually use character 32, but I could see arguments for character 29
> or even 36.� Is there a standard?� Does Read address this anywhere?

When I see a 32 written, I think "Ah!", not "a". (Which doesn't make it wrong, but just tells you my own preference.)

Read's manual, page 16, shows "a/an" written with character 36. See also page 10 discussing vowels with R, which suggests using 36 for several different unstressed vowel sounds.

In a context where the word "a" needs to be emphasized, (e.g., writing "a car", when you might mean "as opposed to two or more cars") I think 29 would be appropriate.


> 2. Should I include a character 26 before a character 21 in a gerund
> such as "eating" or drop the 26?

If the "ing" is a suffix and the previous sound is a consonant you should drop the 26. But -ing following a vowel or a "y" sound probably needs to be spelled with the 26. (Read, p. 18, bottom of page).


> 4. What should be done with words that have multiple, legitimate
> pronunciations?� For example "potato," or "amen."� (1,38,3,29,3,38)
> vs. (1,38,3,32,3,38) or (29,22,28,23) vs. (32,22,28,23)?

Most people will understand these words either way, I think. There seem to be two options. If you know the spelling or pronunciation that is expected by your audience (who are you writing to?), use that. Otherwise, spell it the way you yourself prefer to pronounce it.
